bibl.title: Ben cao gang mu dictionary Vol1

sense.def: Abbreviated Designation shi 螫 , sting; Alternative Names shi nie 螫嚙 , [injury from] sting and bite; ding shi 叮螫， [injury from a] sting. Etiological Agent. of a sting or bite with poisonous teeth by a venomous bug/worm or snake that may generate a poisoning injury affecting either a body region or the entire human body. Ben cao jing ji zhu 本草經集注 Substance Entry shi long zi 石龍子：一種喜緣籬壁，名蝘蜓，形小而 黑，乃言螫人必死 , “An animal that prefers to live in hedges and walls, named yan ting . It is small and black. It is said that when it stings a person , [this person] will have to die”. Ben cao gang mu 本草綱目 lists the following animals that may sting a person: wu song 蜈蚣 , centipede; xie chai 蠍蠆 , scorpion; du she 毒蛇 , poisonous snake; du feng 毒蜂 , poisonous wasp; she xie 蛇蠍 , snakes and scorpions; she feng 蛇蜂 , snakes and bees/wasps; fu she 蝮蛇 , pallas pit viper; zhu she 諸蛇 , all types of snakes; mao chong 毛蟲 , hairy bugs/worms; feng chai 蜂蠆 , bees/wasps and scorpions; sang xie 桑蠍 , mulberry scorpion; shou gong 守宮 , palace guardian; chong yi 蟲蟻 , bugs/worms and ants. It also mentions the animals’ organs causing a sting, such as chong ci 蟲刺 , a worm’s/bug’s sting; xie ci 蠍刺 , a scorpion’s sting, and ran si bei mao 蛅蟖背毛 , hair on the back of ran - si caterpillars.
